The ideaâ€™s backers say itâ€™s just one of several steps California has taken to enable more people to vote.Across the state there were reports of groups collecting ballots and dropping them off at polling places and election offices.â€œWe certainly had that going on here, with people dropping off maybe 100 or 200 ballots,â€ said Neal Kelley, Orange Countyâ€™s registrar of voters. â€œWe also had voters calling and asking if it was legitimate for someone to come to their door and ask if they could take their ballotâ€ and deliver it to the polls.For Democrats, the ballot harvesting was all part of a greater effort to get out the vote from their supporters, particularly from occasional voters.â€œWe beat Republicans on the ground, fair and square,â€ said Katie Merrill, a Democratic consultant deeply involved in November campaigns. â€œMany of the field plans included (ballot harvesting) as an option to deliver voters or their ballotsâ€ to the polls.Those efforts involved identifying voters who might support Democratic candidates and ignoring those who wouldnâ€™t.In one Orange County household, for example, both the husband and wife were longtime Republicans, said Dale Neugebauer, a veteran Republican consultant. Democratic volunteers came by the house four times, each time asking to speak only with their 18-year-old daughter, a no-party-preference voter, and asking if she wanted them to pick up her signed and completed ballot.Thatâ€™s a perfect example of the â€œthorough and disciplinedâ€ ground game the Democrats used, said Merrill.â€œWe were not wasting time talking to people who werenâ€™t going to vote for Democrats,â€ she said.Â Â Â Â

statement: UPDATE TO THIS STORY (12-7-18):According to the Washington Free Beacon, Congresswoman-elect Rashida Tlaib (D., Mich.) did not disclose the name of the source of funds for a fellowship that was paid by liberal billionaire George Sorosâ€”as required by the House ethics committeeâ€”and also disclosed a lesser amount than she received, according to a review of tax and financial disclosure forms.The Washington Free Beacon obtained the most recent copies of tax forms for a number of Sorosâ€™s organizations, including the Open Society Institute, the legal name for the Open Society Foundations, the entity in which Soros pushes millions in funding to a number of liberal causes and organizations.An expenditure of $85,307 to Rashida Tlaib in Detroit, Mich., from 2017 is shown on page 97 of the 321-page report to â€œto increase involvement of disenfranchised urban communities of color with their local governance process by creating a community benefits strategy for equitable development and creating a leadership training for impacted residents focused on negotiation skills and identifying leverage at the local level.â€Tlaib did not report any income in the amount of $85,307 on financial disclosure forms submitted as she was running for office, which identified the names of the sources that provided her income in three of four cases. Tlaib received compensation from the Maurice & Jane Sugar Law Center, Wayne State University, and Metro Solutions, the forms show.Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]However, the fourth reported source of earned income is marked as a â€œLeadership in Government Fellowship,â€ but does not identify who provided the payment.A press release from 2016 shows that Tlaib was chosen for a â€œleadership in governmentâ€ fellowship by Sorosâ€™s Open Society Foundations along with seven other individuals.A spokesman for Sorosâ€™s Open Society Foundations said Tlaibâ€™s fellowship was terminated earlier this year when she informed the group she would be running for Congress..Kendra Arnold, executive director of the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust, a Washington, D.C.-based watchdog group, said that Tlaibâ€™s failure to report the source of her income is â€œproblematicâ€ due to rules requiring that the income source be identified.Candidates are required to disclose the name of groups and organizations that provide their source of income, according to the manual on financial disclosure statements from the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Ethics.The $68,307 income marked for the â€œLeadership in Government Fellowshipâ€ on the financial disclosure forms is also $17,000 less than the $85,307 that was marked as being paid out by Sorosâ€™s group.Arnold said this discrepancy is not as clear and could be the result of hard costs associated with the program.TLAIB WRAPS HERSELF IN PALESTIAN FLAG AFTER WINNING MIDTERM ELECTION:On November 6 2018. Michigan voters in the 13th district, elected Rashida Tlaib to the be their next United States Congresswoman. Tlaib will be filling the seat of the disgraced Democrat Congressman, John Conyers, the longest running member of the House before heÂ was quietly run out of DC amidst several sexual assault allegations against him. While Conyers was a sitting Congressman, his wife, Monica Conyers served a 3-year-term in prison for bribery while she was serving as a Detroit City Congresswoman. Former Congressman John Conyers (D) was hoping that his son would fill his seat, but when John Conyers III came up 1,000 signatures short on his petition to get his name on the primary ballot, Tlaib saw an opening in a weak US Congressional race and capitalized on it.Newsweek celebrated Tlaibâ€™s win.Palestinians in the West Bank cheered on Wednesday morning as they awoke to the news that Rashida Tlaib, a Democrat, had been elected to the U.S. House of Representatives.Representing Michiganâ€™s 13th congressional district, encompassing southwest Detroit and its western suburbs to the city of Dearborn, Tlaib, 42,Â made history, along with Minnesotaâ€™s Ilhan Omar, as they become the first Muslim women elected to Congress. Tlaib is also the first Palestinian-American woman elected to the legislative body. Both also ran on progressive Democrat platforms.She has become â€œa source of pride for Palestine and the entire Arab and Muslim world,â€ Tlaibâ€™s uncle Bassam Tlaib told Reuters in the small Palestinian village of Beit Ur Al-Fauqa.Watch the video below, as Michiganâ€™s first Muslim Congresswoman, Rashida Tlaib can be seen celebrating her victory by wrapping herself in the Palestinian flag and hugging her Palestinian mother.Listen, as she tells the crowd about how proud the PalestiniansÂ on the West Bank are of her nomination to the US Congress, and how theyâ€™re glued to their televisions. You can also hear what appears to be a middle eastern male in the background expressing his enthusiasm, as he almost drowns out the sound of Tlaibâ€™s voice with his celebratory ululation (a shrill sounding tongue trill that is commonly heard in the Middle East).https://twitter.com/KhaledBeydoun/status/1060027114618085377When independent journalist Laura Loomer confronted Tlaib about her support for the terror group,Â Hamas, and asked her why she is campaigning with the open Jew-hating activist Linda Sarsour, Rashida Tlaib attempted to yank Loomerâ€™s phone from her hand.Watch:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BqPcqlXiMDMNewsweek reported â€“ Salem Barahmeh, executive director of the Ramallah-based Palestine Institute for Public Diplomacy, said, â€œTlaibâ€™s election is seen as a glimmer of hope in a very dark chapter in the Palestinian peopleâ€™s history.â€ But Barahmeh also cautioned that â€œchange is incremental, and Palestinians in Palestine are intimately aware of that.â€Â Â

â€œThe dream is still continuing not only in the courts but in our schools,â€ Lynch told a largely black audience. â€œAnd we all know, education is the key. And we understand that discipline is important. We understand that rules are important but we also know that when we sit and look at schools that have the zero tolerance programs, they are often used, and they take our babies, minority children, black children, Hispanic children, and they put them out of school before they have a chance to learn.â€œAnd so the Department of Justice, this past year, has gone into the South, although weâ€™re looking further, and brought the first prison, school-to-prison pipeline cases against school districts in Alabama.â€HEREâ€™S LYNCH (2:00 MARK) TALKING ABOUT â€œOUR BABIESâ€ AND HOW SCHOOL DISCIPLINE IS RACIST:
YOU CAN THANK THE HORRIFIC SHOOTING A PARKLAND HIGH SCHOOL FOR THE POLICY THAT ENABLED THE DISTURBED TEEN TO ESCAPE PUNISHMENT.

statement: Senator Cory Booker is known for speaking before he thinks so the latest gaffe from â€˜Spartacusâ€™ Booker is no surprise. Itâ€™s just a dumb comment and isnâ€™t trueâ€¦AT ALL! And this guy wants to run for POTUS in 2020?Sen. Cory Booker insists Canada is more American than America: â€œI canâ€™t stand how theyâ€™re out-Americaning us in Canada.â€Sen. Cory Booker insists Canada is more American than America: â€œI canâ€™t stand how theyâ€™re out-Americaning us in Canada.â€ pic.twitter.com/Hl4Wis5u7vâ€” Kyle Morris (@RealKyleMorris) October 18, 2018Take it from a Candian that the comment from Booker is idiotic:Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]As a Canadian, I can say that this guy is a complete joke! Right now Canada hates its PM @JustinTrudeau more than Americans dislike Trump. Our incompetent leader is a disgrace. For those looking to leave the US, donâ€™t come across the boarder, we have enough of our own problemsTHIS IS OUR PREVIOUS REPORT ON BOOKER CALLING FOR THE LEFT TO â€œGET UP IN THE FACES OF SOME CONGRESSPEOPLEâ€:Standing in front of a crowd, Booker told the activists to â€œGet up in the face of some Congresspeopleâ€Booker, who has been mentioned as a possible 2020 presidential election candidate, was speaking Wednesday at the National Conference on Ending Homelessness in Washington, D.C.He concluded his address by encouraging people not to be passive, and to instead â€œgo to the Hill today.â€â€œPlease, get up in the face of some congresspeople,â€ he said.Last week, during the Kavanaugh confirmation hearings, the dishonest Senator from New Jersey referred to himself as â€œSpartacusâ€, after he threatened to release emails that were previously marked confidential. BookerÂ threatened that the release of the confidential emails would be damning in nature and would hurt the nomination of Justice Kavanaugh.He was rebuked by Grassley and then Cornyn but then said, â€œBring it, bring itâ€.Booker followed up that bravado with this comment:Â â€œThis is about the closest Iâ€™ll probably ever have in my life to an, â€˜I am Spartacusâ€™ moment.â€During his grandstanding moment, that was carefully orchestrated for the cameras, the 2020Â presidential hopeful was warned by Senator Cornyn to not break the committee rules, and release the documents as Booker was threatening, Â warning him that such an action could cause him to be removed from his position as a US Senator.Booker declared to the Senators in the room that he was prepared to lose his position for the breaking of rules: â€œI am, right now, before your process is finished â€” I am going to release the email about racial profiling. I understand that the penalty comes with potential ousting from the Senate.â€Soon after the grandstanding moment, Bookerâ€™s team released the documents.The fury over the documents led to a letdown for Democrats. The documents only demonstrated that in 2002, soon after the 9/11 attacks, Kavanaugh was against the racial profiling of people while working for the Bush White House. Kavanaugh told colleagues in the email that he favors â€œeffective security measures that are race-neutralâ€ for airports, and he is against â€œrace-basedâ€ remedies for law enforcement in the aftermath of the attack. â€“Daily CallerNot only did the documents end up helping to boost the reputation of Judge Kavanaugh, but they also shined a light on the shameful theatrical nature of the carnival barker Democrat senator from New Jersey, aka â€œSpartacus of New Jerseyâ€.Later in the evening, it was revealed that the documents Booker threatened to release had already been cleared for release and that the whole time, Booker was aware that they were no longer considered confidential. Like pretty much everything the embarrassing Senator, Corey Booker does, it was just for show.
label: fake

It was well thought out and serious. She concluded her speech with more admonishment for those who used Christine Blasey Ford and the #MeToo movement for political purposes. She was fantastic! The video and transcript are below:SENATOR SUSAN COLLINS:Mr. President, the five previous times that I have come to the floor to explain my vote on the nomination of a justice to the United States Supreme Court, I have begun my floor remarks explaining my decision with a recognition of the solemn nature and the importance of the occasion.But today we have come to the conclusion of a confirmation process that has become so dysfunctional it looks more like a caricature of a gutter-level political campaign than a solemn occasion.Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]The President nominated Brett Kavanaugh on July 9th.Â  Within moments of that announcement, special interest groups raced to be the first to oppose him, including one organization that didnâ€™t even bother to fill in the Judgeâ€™s name on its pre-written press release â€“ they simply wrote that they opposed â€œDonald Trumpâ€™s nomination of XX to the Supreme Court of the United States.â€ A number of Senators joined the race to announce their opposition, but they were beaten to the punch by one of our colleagues who actually announced opposition before the nomineeâ€™s identity was even known.Since that time, we have seen special interest groups whip their followers into a frenzy by spreading misrepresentations and outright falsehoods about Judge Kavanaughâ€™s judicial record.Â  Over-the-top rhetoric and distortions of his record and testimony at his first hearing produced short-lived headlines which, although debunked hours later, continue to live on and be spread through social media.Â  Interest groups have also spent an unprecedented amount of dark money opposing this nomination.Our Supreme Court confirmation process has been in steady decline for more than thirty years.Â  One can only hope that the Kavanaugh nomination is where the process has finally hit rock bottom.Against this backdrop, it is up to each individual Senator to decide what the Constitutionâ€™s â€œadvice and consentâ€ duty means.Â  Informed by Alexander Hamiltonâ€™s Federalist 76, I have interpreted this to mean that the President has broad discretion to consider a nomineeâ€™s philosophy, whereas my duty as a Senator is to focus on the nomineeâ€™s qualifications as long as that nomineeâ€™s philosophy is within the mainstream of judicial thought.I have always opposed litmus tests for judicial nominees with respect to their personal views or politics, but I fully expect them to be able to put aside any and all personal preferences in deciding the cases that come before them.Â  I have never considered the Presidentâ€™s identity or party when evaluating Supreme Court nominations.Â  As a result, I voted in favor of Justices Roberts and Alito, who were nominated by President Bush, Justices Sotomayor and Kagan, who were nominated by President Obama, and Justice Gorsuch, who was nominated by President Trump.So I began my evaluation of Judge Kavanaughâ€™s nomination by reviewing his 12-year record on the DC Circuit Court of Appeals, including his more than 300 opinions and his many speeches and law review articles.Â  Nineteen attorneys, including lawyers from the non-partisan Congressional Research Service, briefed me many times each week and assisted me in evaluating the judgeâ€™s extensive record.Â  I met with Judge Kavanaugh for more than two hours in my office.Â  I listened carefully to the testimony at the Committee hearings.Â  I spoke with people who knew him personally, such as Condoleezza Rice and many others.Â  And, I talked with Judge Kavanaugh a second time by phone for another hour to ask him very specific additional questions.I have also met with thousands of my constituents, both advocates and many opponents, regarding Judge Kavanaugh.Â  One concern that I frequently heard was that Judge Kavanaugh would be likely to eliminate the Affordable Care Actâ€™s (ACA) vital protections for people with preexisting conditions.Â  I disagree with this contention.Â  In a dissent in Seven-Sky v. Holder, Judge Kavanaugh rejected a challenge to the ACA on narrow procedural grounds, preserving the law in full.Â  Many experts have said his dissent informed Justice Robertsâ€™ opinion upholding the ACA at the Supreme Court.Furthermore, Judge Kavanaughâ€™s approach toward the doctrine of severability is narrow.Â  When a part of a statute is challenged on constitutional grounds, he has argued for severing the invalid clause as surgically as possible while allowing the overall law to remain intact.This was his approach in his dissent in a case that involved a challenge to the structure of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (PPH v. CFPB).Â  In his dissent, Judge Kavanaugh argued for â€œsevering any problematic portions while leaving the remainder intact.â€Â  Given the current challenges to the ACA, proponents, including myself, of protections for people with pre-existing conditions should want a Justice who would take just this kind of approach.Another assertion I have heard often is that Judge Kavanaugh cannot be trusted if a case involving alleged wrongdoing by the President were to come before the Court.Â  The basis for this argument seems to be two-fold.Â  First, Judge Kavanaugh has written that he believes that Congress should enact legislation to protect presidents from criminal prosecution or civil liability while in office.Â  Mr. President, I believe opponents miss the mark on this issue.Â  The fact that Judge Kavanaugh offered this legislative proposal suggests that he believes that the President does not have such protection currently.Second, there are some who argue that given the current Special Counsel investigation, President Trump should not even be allowed to nominate a justice.Â  That argument ignores our recent history.Â  President Clinton, in 1993, nominated Justice Ginsburg after the Whitewater investigation was already underway.Â  And she was confirmed 96-3.Â  The next year, just three months after Independent Counsel Robert Fiske was named to lead the Whitewater investigation, President Clinton nominated Justice Breyer.Â  He was confirmed 87-9.Supreme Court Justices have not hesitated to rule against the presidents who have nominated them.Â  Perhaps most notably in United States v. Nixon, three Nixon appointees who heard the case joined the unanimous opinion against him.Judge Kavanaugh has been unequivocal in his belief that no president is above the law.Â  He has stated that Marbury v. Madison, Youngstown Steel v. Sawyer and United States v. Nixon are three of the four greatest Supreme Court cases in history.Â  What do they have in common?Â  Each of them is a case where the Court served as a check on presidential power.Â  And I would note that the fourth case that Judge Kavanaugh has pointed to as the greatest in history was Brown v Board of Education.One Kavanaugh decision illustrates theÂ  point about the check on presidential power directly.Â  He wrote the opinion in Hamdan v. United States, a case that challenged the Bush Administrationâ€™s military commission prosecution of an associate of Osama Bin Laden.Â  This conviction was very important to the Bush Administration, but Judge Kavanaugh, who had been appointed to the DC Circuit by President Bush and had worked in President Bushâ€™s White House, ruled that the conviction was unlawful.Â  As he explained during the hearing, â€œWe donâ€™t make decisions based on who people are, or their policy preferences, or the moment.Â  We base decisions on the lawâ€¦.â€Others I met with have expressed concerns that Justice Kennedyâ€™s retirement threatens the right of same sex couples to marry.Â  Yet, Judge Kavanaugh described the Obergefell decision, which legalized same gender marriages, as an important landmark precedent.Â  He also cited Justice Kennedyâ€™s recent Masterpiece Cakeshop opinion for the Courtâ€™s majority stating that: â€œThe days of treating gay and lesbian Americans or gay and lesbian couples as second-class citizens who are inferior in dignity and worth are over in the Supreme Court.â€Others have suggested that the judge holds extreme views on birth control.Â  In one case, Judge Kavanaugh incurred the disfavor of both sides of the political spectrum for seeking to ensure the availability of contraceptive services for women while minimizing the involvement of employers with religious objections.Â  Although his critics frequently overlook this point, Judge Kavanaughâ€™s dissent rejected arguments that the government did not have a compelling interest in facilitating access to contraception.Â  In fact, he wrote that the Supreme Court precedent â€œstrongly suggestedâ€ that there was a â€œcompelling interestâ€ in facilitating access to birth control.There has also been considerable focus on the future of abortion rights based on the concern that Judge Kavanaugh would seek to overturn Roe v. Wade.Â  Protecting this right is important to me.To my knowledge, Judge Kavanaugh is the first Supreme Court nominee to express the view that precedent is not merely a practice and tradition, but rooted in Article III of our Constitution itself.Â  He believes that precedent â€œis not just a judicial policy â€¦ it is constitutionally dictated to pay attention and pay heed to rules of precedent.â€Â  In other words, precedent isnâ€™t a goal or an aspiration; it is a constitutional tenet that has to be followed except in the most extraordinary circumstances.The judge further explained that precedent provides stability, predictability, reliance, and fairness.Â  There are, of course, rare and extraordinary times where the Supreme Court would rightly overturn a precedent.Â  The most famous example was when the Supreme Court in Brown v. Board of Education overruled Plessy v. Ferguson, correcting a â€œgrievously wrongâ€ decisionâ€“to use the judgeâ€™s termâ€“allowing racial inequality.Â  But, someone who believes that the importance of precedent has been rooted in the Constitution would follow long-established precedent except in those rare circumstances where a decision is â€œgrievously wrongâ€ or â€œdeeply inconsistent with the law.â€Â  Those are Judge Kavanaughâ€™s phrases.As Judge Kavanaugh asserted to me, a long-established precedent is not something to be trimmed, narrowed, discarded, or overlooked.Â  Its roots in the Constitution give the concept of stare decisis greater weight such that precedent canâ€™t be trimmed or narrowed simply because a judge might want to on a whim.Â  In short, his views on honoring precedent would preclude attempts to do by stealth that which one has committed not to do overtly.Noting that Roe v. Wade was decided 45 years ago, and reaffirmed 19 years later in Planned Parenthood v. Casey, I asked Judge Kavanaugh whether the passage of time is relevant to following precedent.Â  He said decisions become part of our legal framework with the passage of time and that honoring precedent is essential to maintaining public confidence.Our discussion then turned to the right of privacy, on which the Supreme Court relied in Griswold v. Connecticut, a case that struck down a law banning the use and sale of contraceptives.Â  Griswold established the legal foundation that led to Roe eight years later.Â  In describing Griswold as â€œsettled law,â€ Judge Kavanaugh observed that it was the correct application of two famous cases from the 1920s, Meyer and Pierce, that are not seriously challenged by anyone today.Â  Finally, in his testimony, he noted repeatedly that Roe had been upheld by Planned Parenthood v. Casey, describing it as â€œprecedent on precedent.â€Â  When I asked him would it be sufficient to overturn a long-established precedent if five current justices believed it was wrongly decided, he emphatically said â€œno.â€Opponents frequently cite then-candidate Donald Trumpâ€™s campaign pledge to nominate only judges who would overturn Roe.Â  The Republican platform for all presidential campaigns has included this pledge since at least 1980.Â  During this time, Republican presidents have appointed Justices Oâ€™Connor, Souter, and Kennedy to the Supreme Court.Â  These are the very three justicesâ€”Republican president appointed justicesâ€”who authored the Casey decision, which reaffirmed Roe.Â  Furthermore, pro-choice groups vigorously opposed each of these justicesâ€™ nominations.Â  Incredibly, they even circulated buttons with the slogan â€œStop Souter Or Women Will Die!â€Â  Just two years later, Justice Souter coauthored the Casey opinion, reaffirming a womanâ€™s right to choose.Â  Suffice it to say, prominent advocacy organizations have been wrong.These same interest groups have speculated that Judge Kavanaugh was selected to do the bidding of conservative ideologues, despite his record of judicial independence.Â  I asked the judge point blank whether he had made any commitments or pledges to anyone at the White House, to the Federalist Society, or to any outside group on how he would decide cases.Â  He unequivocally assured me he had not.Judge Kavanaugh has received rave reviews for his 12-year track record as a judge, including for his judicial temperament.Â  The American Bar Association (ABA) gave him its highest possible rating.Â  Its Standing Committee on the Federal Judiciary conducted an extraordinarily thorough assessment, soliciting input from almost 500 people, including his judicial colleagues.Â  The ABA concluded that â€œhis integrity, judicial temperament, and professional competence met the highest standard.â€Lisa Blatt, who has argued more cases before the Supreme Court than any other woman in history, testified: â€œBy any objective measure, Judge Kavanaugh is clearly qualified to serve on the Supreme Court.â€Â  â€œHis opinions are invariably thoughtful and fairâ€¦.â€Â  Ms. Blatt, who clerked for and is an ardent admirer of Justice Ginsburg, and who is, in her own words, â€œan unapologetic defender of a womanâ€™s right to choose,â€ said that Judge Kavanaugh â€œfit[s] in the mainstream of legal thought.â€Â  She also observed that â€œJudge Kavanaugh is remarkably committed to promoting women in the legal profession.â€That Judge Kavanaugh is more of a centrist than some of his critics maintain is reflected in the fact that he and Chief Judge Merrick Garland voted the same way in 93 percent of the cases that they heard together.Â  Indeed, Chief Judge Garland joined in more than 96 percent of the majority opinions authored by Judge Kavanaugh, dissenting only once.Despite all this, after weeks of reviewing Judge Kavanaughâ€™s record and listening to 32 hours of his testimony, the Senateâ€™s advice and consent role was thrown into a tailspin following the allegations of sexual assault by Professor Christine Blasey Ford.Â  The confirmation process now involves evaluating whether or not Judge Kavanaugh committed sexual assault, and lied about it to the Judiciary Committee.Some argue that because this is a lifetime appointment to our highest court, the public interest requires that doubts be resolved against the nominee.Â  Others see the public interest as embodied in our long-established tradition of affording to those accused of misconduct a presumption of innocence.Â  In cases in which the facts are unclear, they would argue that the question should be resolved in favor of the nominee.Mr. President, I understand both viewpoints.Â  This debate is complicated further by the fact that the Senate confirmation process is not a trial.Â  But certain fundamental legal principlesâ€”about due process, the presumption of innocence, and fairnessâ€”do bear on my thinking, and I cannot abandon them.In evaluating any given claim of misconduct, we will be ill served in the long run if we abandon the presumption of innocence and fairness, tempting though it may be.Â  We must always remember that it is when passions are most inflamed that fairness is most in jeopardy.The presumption of innocence is relevant to the advice and consent function when an accusation departs from a nomineeâ€™s otherwise exemplary record.Â  I worry that departing from this presumption could lead to a lack of public faith in the judiciary and would be hugely damaging to the confirmation process moving forward.Some of the allegations levied against Judge Kavanaugh illustrate why the presumption of innocence is so important.Â  I am thinking in particular not of the allegations raised by Professor Ford, but of the allegation that, when he was a teenager, Judge Kavanaugh drugged multiple girls and used their weakened state to facilitate gang rape.Â  This outlandish allegation was put forth without any credible supporting evidence and simply parroted public statements of others.Â  That such an allegation can find its way into the Supreme Court confirmation process is a stark reminder about why the presumption of innocence is so ingrained in our American consciousness.Mr. President, I listened carefully to Christine Blasey Fordâ€™s testimony before the Judiciary Committee.Â  I found her testimony to be sincere, painful, and compelling.Â  I believe that she is a survivor of a sexual assault and that this trauma has upended her life.Â  Nevertheless, the four witnesses she named could not corroborate any of the events of that evening gathering where she says the assault occurred; none of the individuals Professor Ford says were at the party has any recollection at all of that night.Judge Kavanaugh forcefully denied the allegations under penalty of perjury.Â  Mark Judge denied under penalty of felony that he had witnessed an assault.Â  PJ Smyth, another person allegedly at the party, denied that he was there under penalty of felony.Â  Professor Fordâ€™s life-long friend Leland Keyser indicated that, under penalty of felony, she does not remember that party.Â  And Ms. Keyser went further.Â  She indicated that not only does she not remember a night like that, but also that she does not even know Brett Kavanaugh.In addition to the lack of corroborating evidence, we also learned some facts that raised more questions.Â  For instance, since these allegations have become public, Professor Ford testified that not a single person has contacted her to say, â€œI was at the party that night.â€Furthermore, the professor testified that although she does not remember how she got home that evening, she knew that, because of the distance, she would have needed a ride â€“ yet not a single person has come forward to say that they were the one that drove her home or were in the car with her that night.Â  And Professor Ford also indicated that even though she left that small gathering of six or so people abruptly and without saying goodbye and distraught, none of them called her the next day â€“ or ever â€“ to ask why she left â€“ is she okay â€“ not even her closest friend, Ms. Keyser.Mr. President, the Constitution does not provide guidance as to how we are supposed to evaluate these competing claims.Â  It leaves that decision up to each Senator.Â  This is not a criminal trial, and I do not believe that claims such as these need to be proved beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Nevertheless, fairness would dictate that the claims at least should meet a threshold of â€œmore likely than notâ€ as our standard.The facts presented do not mean that Professor Ford was not sexually assaulted that night â€“ or at some other time â€“ but they do lead me to conclude that the allegations fail to meet the â€œmore likely than notâ€ standard.Â  Therefore, I do not believe that these charges can fairly prevent Judge Kavanaugh from serving on the Court.Let me emphasize that my approach to this question should not be misconstrued as suggesting that unwanted sexual contact of any nature is not a serious problem in this country.Â  To the contrary, if any good at all has come from this ugly confirmation process, it has been to create an awareness that we have underestimated the pervasiveness of this terrible problem.I have been alarmed and disturbed, however, by some who have suggested that unless Judge Kavanaughâ€™s nomination is rejected, the Senate is somehow condoning sexual assault.Â  Nothing could be further from the truth.Every personâ€”man or womanâ€“who makes a charge of sexual assault deserves to be heard and treated with respect. Â The #MeToo movement is real.Â  It matters.Â  It is needed.Â  And it is long overdue. We know that rape and sexual assault are less likely to be reported to the police than other forms of assault.Â  On average, an estimated 211,000 rapes and sexual assaults go unreported every year. We must listen to survivors, and every day we must seek to stop the criminal behavior that has hurt so many.Â  We owe this to ourselves, our children, and generations to come.Since the hearing, I have listened to many survivors of sexual assault.Â  Many were total strangers who told me their heart-wrenching stories for the first time in their lives.Â  Some were friends I have known for decades, yet with the exception of one woman who had confided in me years ago, I had no idea that they had been the victims of sexual attacks.Â  I am grateful for their courage and their willingness to come forward, and I hope that in heightening public awareness, they have also lightened the burden that they have been quietly bearing for so many years.Â  To them, I pledge to do all that I can to ensure that their daughters and granddaughters never share their experiences.Over the past few weeks, I have been emphatic that the Senate has an obligation to investigate and evaluate the serious allegations of sexual assault.Â  I called for and supported the additional hearing to hear from both Professor Ford and Judge Kavanaugh.Â  I also pushed for and supported the FBI supplemental background investigation. Â This was the right thing to do.Christine Ford never sought the spotlight.Â  She indicated that she was terrified to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee, and she has shunned attention since then.Â  She seemed completely unaware of Chairman Grassleyâ€™s offer to allow her to testify confidentially in California.Â  Watching her, Mr. President, I could not help but feel that some people who wanted to engineer the defeat of this nomination cared little, if at all, for her well-being.Professor Ford testified that a very limited number of people had access to her letter.Â  Yet that letter found its way into the public domain.Â  She testified that she never gave permission for that very private letter to be released.Â  And yet, here we are.Â  We are in the middle of a fight that she never sought, arguing about claims that she wanted to raise confidentially.One theory I have heard espoused repeatedly is that our colleague, Senator Feinstein, leaked Professor Fordâ€™s letter at the eleventh hour to derail this process.Â  I want to state this very clearly:Â I know Senator Diane Feinstein extremely well, and I believe that she would never do that.Â  I knew that to be the case before she even stated it at the hearing.Â  She is a person of integrity, and I stand by her.I have also heard some argue that the Chairman of the Committee somehow treated Professor Ford unfairly.Â  Nothing could be further from the truth.Â  Chairman Grassley, along with his excellent staff, treated Professor Ford with compassion and respect throughout the entire process.Â  And that is the way the Senator from Iowa has conducted himself throughout a lifetime dedicated to public service.But the fact remains, Mr. President, that someone leaked this letter against Professor Fordâ€™s express wishes.Â  I suspect, regrettably, that we will never know for certain who did it.Â  To that leaker, who I hope is listening now, let me say that what you did was unconscionable.Â  You have taken a survivor who was not only entitled to your respect, but who also trusted you to protect her â€“ and you have sacrificed her well-being in a misguided attempt to win whatever political crusade you think you are fighting.Â  My only hope is that your callous act has turned this process into such a dysfunctional circus that it will cause the Senate â€“ and indeed all Americans â€“ to reconsider how we evaluate Supreme Court nominees.Â  If that happens, then the appalling lack of compassion you afforded Professor Ford will at least have some unintended positive consequences.Mr. President, the politically charged atmosphere surrounding this nomination had reached a fever pitch even before these allegations were known, and it has been challenging even then to separate fact from fiction.We live in a time of such great disunity, as the bitter fight over this nomination both in the Senate and among the public clearly demonstrates.Â  It is not merely a case of different groups having different opinions.Â  It is a case of people bearing extreme ill will toward those who disagree with them.Â  In our intense focus on our differences, we have forgotten the common values that bind us together as Americans.Â  When some of our best minds are seeking to develop ever more sophisticated algorithms designed to link us to websites that only reinforce and cater to our views, we can only expect our differences to intensify.This would have alarmed the drafters of our Constitution, who were acutely aware that different values and interests could prevent Americans from becoming and remaining a single people.Â  Indeed, of the six objectives they invoked in the preamble to the Constitution, the one that they put first was the formation of â€œa more perfect Union.â€Their vision of â€œa more perfect Unionâ€ does not exist today, and if anything, we appear to be moving farther away from it.Â  It is particularly worrisome that the Supreme Court, the institution that most Americans see as the principal guardian of our shared constitutional heritage, is viewed as part of the problem through a political lens.Mr. President, weâ€™ve heard a lot of charges and counter charges about Judge Kavanaugh.Â  But as those who have known him best have attested, he has been an exemplary public servant, judge, teacher, coach, husband, and father.Â  Despite the turbulent, bitter fight surrounding his nomination, my fervent hope is that Brett Kavanaugh will work to lessen the divisions in the Supreme Court so that we have far fewer 5-4 decisions and so that public confidence in our Judiciary and our highest court is restored.Â  Mr. President, I will vote to confirm Judge Kavanaugh.

Here is what Ford said:Leland has significant health challenges, and Iâ€™m happy that sheâ€™s focusing on herself and getting the health treatment that she needs, and she let me know that she needed her lawyer to take care of this for her, and she texted me right afterward with an apology and good wishes, and et cetera. So Iâ€™m glad that sheâ€™s taking care of herself.I donâ€™t expect that P.J. and Leland would remember this evening. It was a very unremarkable party. They were downstairs.Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]As attorneys for Christine Ford Blasey demanded an FBI investigation over the last two weeks, the Wall Street Journal reports that her allies were pressuring one witness to change her story. Ford named Leland Keyser as one of four potential witnesses to the Washington Post, but once her name became public, Keyser issued a statement through her attorneys that she cannot recall ever being at a party with Brett Kavanaugh. â€“Hot AirA friend of Christine Blasey Ford told FBI investigators that she felt pressured by Dr. Fordâ€™s allies to revisit her initial statement that she knew nothing about an alleged sexual assault by a teenage Brett Kavanaugh, which she later updated to say that she believed but couldnâ€™t corroborate Dr. Fordâ€™s account, according to people familiar with the matter.Leland Keyser, who Dr. Ford has said was present at the gathering where she was allegedly assaulted in the 1980s, told investigators that Monica McLean, a retired Federal Bureau of Investigation agent and a friend of Dr. Fordâ€™s, had urged her to clarify her statement, the people said. â€¦On Thursday, a day after sending toÂ the White House the reportÂ on its investigation into the allegations against Judge Kavanaugh, the FBI sent the White House and Senate an additional package of information that included text messages from Ms. McLean to Ms. Keyser, according to a person familiar with the matter.Watch:The Conservative Treehouse does a brilliant job of breaking down the ties to Kavanaugh accuser Christine Blasey Ford and her former FBI agent friend Monical L. McLean, who Leyland Keyser claims was pressuring her to change her story about Kavanaugh.In a letter released from a former boyfriend of Christine Blasey-Ford, there was a name curiously not redacted. The name of Monica L McLean was revealed as a life-long friend who Ms. Ford helped with polygraph preparation.The media has begun to focus on the letter as outlining a lie told by Ms. Ford during recent congressional testimonyâ€¦ But the backstory to Ms. Monica Lee McLean is an even bigger story.First the letter from the boyfriend:McLean also came to the defense of Ford in a letter from former classmates at Holton-Arms private high school, where the two were classmates.Â Some research into Ms. Fordâ€™s life-long friend from school, Ms. Monica Lee McLean (DOB 03-15-66), reveals an almost guaranteed likelihood the polygraph assistance had something to do with the career path Ms. McLean would take.Monica Lee McLean was admitted to the California Bar in 1992, the same year Ms. Fordâ€™s boyfriend stated he began a six-year relationship with her best friend.Â  The address for the current inactive California Law License is now listed as *â€Rehoboth Beach, DEâ€.Â  [*Note* remember this, it becomes more relevant later.]In a 2000 Los Angeles FBI declaration Ms. McLean describes herself as a Special Agent of the FBI, Associate Division Counsel, in the Los Angeles Division Legal Unit:After 2003, Ms. Monica L McLean is working with the SDNY as a Public Information Officer for the FBI New York Field Office, side-by-side with SDNY Attorney General Preet Bharara:On Sept 28, Bharara questioned Senator Flakeâ€™s committment to standing against Kavanaugh, he also pushed for an FBI investigation:If Flake flakes once can he not flake again? Are other Republican Senators joining him? https://t.co/8OnPzjTpTtâ€” Preet Bharara (@PreetBharara) September 28, 2018On September 29, Bharara tweeted about his concern about President Trump limiting the FBI investigation into sexual assault allegations against Judge Kavanaugh.Will WH counsel clearly and on the record confirm this? https://t.co/osoC5yvSxFâ€” Preet Bharara (@PreetBharara) September 30, 2018According to her LinkedIn profile, Ms. McLean retired from the FBI in 2016, after 24 years of work.Â  [*It should be noted that Ms. McLeanâ€™s PIO partner in New York, Jim Margolin, is still currently employed there; and coincidentally attached to the case against President Trumpâ€™s former lawyer, Michael Cohen.]According to her LinkedIn background, Ms. Monica Lee McLean, was a 24-year employee of the Department of Justice and FBI from 1992 to 2016.Â  According to public records Ms. McLean worked in both Los Angeles, CA and New York, NY.In an April, 2016, article in the Delaware Cape Gazette, Mrs. McLean shows up at a wine tasting event; and is pictured within the publication:This article confirms the location of Monica McLean in relationship to the numerous public record citations of her Delaware residence.Hereâ€™s where things get really interesting.Ms. Blasey-Ford and Ms. McLean, the BFF she coached on lie detector testing, together for the four days leading up to the actual writing of the letter.Â  July 26th to July 30th.Ms. Monica Lee McLean and Ms. Christine Blasey-Ford are life-long friends; obviously, they have known each other since their High School days at Holton-Arms, and both lived together as â€œroommatesâ€ in California after college. Â  Their close friendship is cited by Ms. Fordâ€™s former boyfriend of six years.Ms. Monica McLean retired from the FBI in 2016; apparently right after the presidential election.Â  Her current residence is listed at Rehoboth Beach, Delaware; which aligns with public records and the serendipitous printed article.MITCHELL: The second is the letter that you wrote to Senator Feinstein, dated the â€” July 30th of this year.MITCHELL: Did you write the letter yourself?FORD: I did.MITCHELL: And I â€” since itâ€™s dated July 30th, did you write it on that date?FORD: I believe so. I â€” it sounds right. I was in Rehoboth, Delaware, at the time. I could look into my calendar and try to figure that out. It seemedâ€¦MITCHELL: Was it written on or about that date?FORD: Yes, yes. I traveled, I think, the 26th of July to Rehoboth, Delaware. So that makes sense, because I wrote it from there.MITCHELL: Is the letter accurate? FORD: Iâ€™ll take a minute to read it.So we have Dr. Blasey-Ford in Rehoboth Beach, DE, on 26th July 2018. Weâ€™ve got her life-long BFF, Monica L McLean, who worked as attorney and POI in the DOJ/FBI in Rehoboth Beach, DEâ€¦. Apparently at the same time she wrote the letter to Senator Dianne Feinstein.It would appear that Ms. Blasey-Ford was with Ms. Monica L McLean, the retired FBI agent and former New York field office spokesperson, at the time she wrote the letter to Senator Feinstein.That would certainly begin to explain quite a bit about who exactly was handling Ms. Ford; and how there would be an intentional effort, from a subject matter expert, on how to best position the attack against Brett Kavanaugh.Who better to help scrub the internet history, and know what processes and people to enlist in such preparatory work, than a retired lawyer who worked deep inside the FBI?Not only did Ms. McLean possesses a particular set of skills to assist Ms. Ford, but Ms. McLean would also have a network of DOJ and FBI resources to assist in the endeavor.Â  A former friendly FBI agent to do the polygraph; a network of politically motivated allies?Does the appearance of FBI insider and Deputy FBI Director to Andrew McCabe, Michael Bromwich, begin to make more sense?Do the loud and overwhelming requests by political allies for FBI intervention, take on a different meaning or make more sense, now?Standing back and taking a look at the bigger, BIG PICTUREâ€¦.. could it be that Mrs. McLean and her team of ideological compatriots within the DOJ and FBI, who have massive axes to grind against the current Trump administration, are behind this entire endeavor?David Laufman was the Department of Justice â€“ National Security Division, Deputy Asst. Attorney General in charge of counterintelligence, cyber security, counterespionage and export controls.Â  He was inside the DOJ-NSD when the FISA application against Carter Page, and by extension the Trump campaign, was constructed, submitted and approved.If there was any doubt the â€œsmall groupâ€ of connected DOJ and FBI officials were behind the use of Ms. Ford, you can put that doubt away now that Ms. Fordâ€™s handler, Monica McLean, has enlisted David Laufman as her legal defense.Theyâ€™re not even trying to hide it anymore.Michael Bromwich is representing Ms. Ford, and David Laufman is representing Ms. McLean.Â Â  The concentric Lawfare gang is working overtime, likely pro-bono.It is beyond obvious now that Ms. Christine Blasey-Ford was not just some random ancillary high school acquaintance of Brett Kavanaugh; Ms. Ford appears to have been selected by a group of politically connected FBI and DOJ officials for the purpose of targeting Judge Kavanaugh.All of these DOJ and FBI people are part of a tight network.â€œBeach Friendsâ€?Â  Rohoboth Beach friends?Â

Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) and her entire office are now facing investigation after the way they handled the confidential letter provided to Feinstein from Judge Brett Kavanaughâ€™s first accuser, Christine Blasey Ford.According to Sen. Tom Cotton (R-AR), Feinsteinâ€™s office will be investigated in hopes of determining who leaked Fordâ€™s letter to the press, with the Intercept being one of the first publications to publish about it. The letter was to remain confidential per request of Ford, but it clearly became public and ended up in the hands of someone in the press, likely a leftist leaning publication/website.Sen. Cotton also stated that lawyers who were recommended to Ford are also facing investigation by the D.C. bar for what they did to Ford. They allegedly did not tell Ford that the Senate Judiciary Committee offered to travel to California to interview her regarding her accusations against Kavanaugh.During Fordâ€™s testimony last week, she made it seem like she did not know that the committee would fly out to her. When Ford delayed the questioning that was set for a Monday, people had thought she was stalling to get her story straight. Technically, it was not Ford stalling. It was allegedly her attorneys who are working pro-bono and are apparently quite friendly with Democrats. statement: A big update just hit the newswires and the Senate Judiciary Committee has stated that Judge Brett Kavanaughâ€™s vote is scheduled. They finally agreed on a date and set it for this Friday at 9:30 am.This is one day after Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford are scheduled to testify in front of lawmakers on the sexual assault accusations brought forward by Ford. These are accusations that suggest Kavanaugh tried to take her clothes off at a party, but Kavanaugh denies all accusations and Fordâ€™s story from over 30 years ago doesnâ€™t quite add up.It looks like they want to get the job done and stop playing games with Democrats.Sen. Her claim was that Kavanaugh exposed himself to her while he was intoxicated at a college party back in the 1980â€™s, an allegation that Kavanaugh has also denied.Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]Fox News has learned that Judiciary Committee staffers interviewed Kavanaugh by phone about the Ramirez allegations on Tuesday. A source familiar with the call told Fox News that Republican staffers led the interview, while Democratic aides listened without asking any questions.Fox News stated that a successful vote this Friday isnâ€™t required to push him to the Senate. â€œCurrent Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas received no recommendation from the Judiciary Committee in 1991, but was still confirmed by the Senate. Conversely, Robert Bork received an unfavorable recognition from the committee in 1987, though his nomination was rejected by the full Senate.â€Politico also reported â€œSenate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) can bring Kavanaugh to the floor whether the nominee gets a favorable or unfavorable recommendation. Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) is undecided on Kavanaughâ€™s nomination and is the key swing vote on the panel; Flake has not voted in the Senate this week and has not commented on his current thinking about Kavanaugh.â€œFor Republicans to schedule a Friday vote on Brett Kavanaugh today, two days before Dr. Blasey Ford has had a chance to tell her story, is outrageous,â€ said Sen Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), the committeeâ€™s ranking member. â€œFirst Republicans demanded Dr. Blasey Ford testify immediately. Now Republicans donâ€™t even need to hear her before they move ahead with a vote.â€If you think about the timeline of events, Brett Kavanaugh could be confirmed by now if there was no sideshow brought to town by Democrat resisters.Even if Christine Blasey Ford testified yesterday, as she was originally invited to, that means Kavanaugh could have been voted on today.The Democrats seem to have a stalling tactic underway as they keep trying to dig up old accusations, or possibly make them up as they go along.Kavanaugh should be presumed innocent unless proven guilty.This could turn out to be a massive smear campaign by anti-Trumpers.It was previously reported that Diane Feinstein wasnâ€™t certain if Christine Blasey Ford will show up. Ford has had some demands, but itâ€™s unsure if theyâ€™ll be met. She has to remember that she doesnâ€™t run the show and when sheâ€™s given the opportunity to have her voice heard, then she should take it and stop making so many demands.NEW: Sen. statement: Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh is getting slammed by all ends of the media right now. Heâ€™s facing one of the biggest character assassinations that I can ever remember in a what appears to be a massive smear campaign by Democrats looking to undermine the work of President Trump and basically attack anyone he selects for just about anything.This guy canâ€™t catch a break and heâ€™s being dragged into a huge mess that all appears to be a big project by Democrats to take him down. Of course, it seems that way based on the evidence and incidents going on thus far. Everything with Christine Blasey Ford, that other accuser (whose name I left out because thereâ€™s nothing credible in her story, even less credible than Fordâ€™s), and the Democratic Party seem to be attempting to push Kavanaugh to the edge in hopes that he quits or they turn a few confirmation votes against him.Now the police department in Marylandâ€™s Montgomery County is getting involved and theyâ€™ve issued a statement on whatâ€™s going on.Their latest statement regarding the alleged victims and their accusations pertaining to Kavanaugh and his accuser/s is in full, below.Statement from the Montgomery County Police Department Regarding Victim Accusations of Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh: https://t.co/U8dK2jTYz3â€” Montgomery County Department of Police (@mcpnews) September 24, 2018Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]September 24, 2018Statement from the Montgomery County Police Department Regarding Victim Accusations of Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh:At this time, the Montgomery County Police Department has not received a request by any alleged victim nor a victimâ€™s attorney to initiate a police report or a criminal investigation regarding Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh.The Department recognizes that victims of sexual assault may not want to involve law enforcement and/or initiate a criminal investigation, and we respect that position. The Department, however, stands prepared to assist anyone who reports being the victim of a sexual assault.Typically, in a sexual assault case, the cooperation of the victim or witnesses is necessary. As with any criminal investigation, a determination must be made as to the jurisdiction where the alleged offense occurred and the specific details of the event to establish a potential criminal charge.Our Department is ready to investigate any claim of sexual assault that is alleged to have occurred within our County.Hereâ€™s where that gets murky. If thereâ€™s an accusation of sexual assault, then why did Christine Blasey Ford go to Diane Feinstein instead of the police? If thereâ€™s a second accuser, then why didnâ€™t that person go to the police? Sounds a bit weird, right?Here is the police department, the one likely to receive the call, who is saying that 1) no one has filed any reports of said alleged crimes, and 2) theyâ€™re ready to do the work if needed.This is why we cannot just outright believe someoneâ€™s accusations from that many years ago without substantial evidence. Had there been a police report from three decades ago, then there would be something concrete that people could utilize. But thereâ€™s nothing. There is just the word of the accuser vs the word of the accused, and right about now the accused is looking very innocent.Based on everything thatâ€™s going on with Ford and her accusations and her inability to locate a credible witness who supports her claims, thereâ€™s just nothing going on there thatâ€™s worth looking at Kavanaugh differently.How can you destroy a manâ€™s character with wild accusations like this?Based on the lack of evidence and what looks to be a massive character take-down plot by the Democrats, I can only imagine this circus gets more bizarre before someone finally shuts the door and proceeds with the confirmation of Kavanaugh.Bill Cosby was found guilty for crimes done many years ago, but how many actual witnesses were there? Quite a few. Itâ€™s one thing to have that many people telling the same story about his alleged sexual misconduct and itâ€™s easier to find him guilty.However, Christine Blasey Ford is just one person with a slightly shakey story, no witnesses, and basically no one to vouch for her story that it even happened. Her collaboration with Democrats puts an extra damper on it as well.I donâ€™t know about you, but when someone commits a crime, then I would call the police â€“ not the politicians 30+ years later.Calling the police makes sense.Calling a politician does not.Whatâ€™s really going on here?

So now that the hurricane has been downgraded to a category 1 storm, should President Trump take the credit for the downgrade?Wednesday on the radio, LevinTV host Mark Levin poured out his contempt for the media, which is already blaming President Donald Trump for the coming disaster of Hurricane Florence.â€œWeâ€™re seeing our fellow Americans having to flee about one quarter of the United States geographically â€” millions â€” because their lives, their property, their livelihoods are threatened by Mother Nature,â€ Levin said. â€œAnd MSNBC and CNN and the Democrats are already blaming Trump.â€â€œIt is impossible for the federal government to be everywhere with the kind of personnel and resources that are necessary to address these natural disasters,â€ Levin continued, showing how deranged these attacks on Trump are.â€œAnd then you have these political ambulance chasers and these media ambulance chasers who are already positioning themselves to attack the president.â€ â€“Conservative ReviewTrending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]Listen:Although Hurricane Florence, which threatened to be a catergory 4 or 5 storm, has been downgraded to a category 1 storm, Fox News claims that State officials are bracing for the worst.A tattered American flag seen flying on a live surf camera at Frying Pan Tower in North Carolina is evidence of the strong wind gusts pounding the coast.â€œHurricane-force windsâ€ had begun hitting the stateâ€™s coast, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) said in an 11 p.m. EDT update.Even though Florenceâ€™s winds weakened as it drew closer to land, dropping from a peak of 140 mph earlier in the week, North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper maintained his warning.â€œDonâ€™t relax, donâ€™t get complacent. Stay on guard. This is a powerful storm that can kill. Today the threat becomes a reality,â€ Cooper said.The core of the storm is about 60 miles east-southeast of Wilmington, North Carolina about 50 miles south of Morehead, City, North Carolina, the NHC said.Florence is moving northwest at 5 mph with maximum sustained winds of 90 mph, the update said.To be clear, weâ€™re not downplaying the severity of this storm, weâ€™re just pointing out the idiocy of blaming President Trump (or any president for that matter) for a potentially life-threatening storm.The National Hurricane Center is warning of the danger the category 1 storm poses for residents who are near the shore, lakes or rivers that may cause flash floods.#Florence is expected to bring a life-threatening storm surge to portions of eastern North & South Carolina, and catastrophic flash flooding and prolonged significant river flooding are likely over portions of the Carolinas and the southern/central Appalachians. pic.twitter.com/j6HZco1Tscâ€” National Hurricane Center (@NHC_Atlantic) September 14, 2018

Kavanaugh told colleagues in the email that he favors â€œeffective security measures that are race-neutralâ€ for airports, and he is against â€œrace-basedâ€ remedies for law enforcement in the aftermath of the attack. â€“Daily CallerNot only did the documents end up helping to boost the reputation of Judge Kavanaugh, but they also shined a light on the shameful theatrical nature of the carnival barker Democrat senator from New Jersey, aka â€œSpartacus of New Jerseyâ€.Later in the evening, it was revealed that the documents Booker threatened to release had already been cleared for release and that the whole time, Booker was aware that they were no longer considered confidential. It is a political institutionâ€¦Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg told an Egyptian TV station in 2012 that she would not recommend using the U.S. Constitution as a model for writing a modern-day constitutionSupreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg told an Egyptian TV station in 2012 that she would not recommend using the U.S. Constitution as a model for writing a modern-day constitution. pic.twitter.com/QxSIMoIMDAâ€” Ryan Saavedra (@RealSaavedra) July 9, 2018â€œWELL, SOME THINGS Iâ€™D LIKE TO CHANGE, ONE IS THE ELECTORAL COLLEGEâ€ â€“ RBGSupreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg got the crowd worked up when during a speech at Stanford University she said sheâ€™d support the abolition of the Electoral College.Â She was asked which constitutional provisions should â€œevolve with the societyâ€:
â€œWell, some things I would like to change, one is the electoral college,â€ she said, to rapturous applause. â€œBut that would require a constitutional amendment. Amending our constitution is powerfully hard to do, as I know from the struggle for the Equal Rights Amendment, which fell three state shy [of passage].
So much for the SCOTUS being apoliticalâ€¦Check out her comments on equality for women. Itâ€™s like sheâ€™s time traveled back to the 50â€™s. What is the deal with these women that think weâ€™re still in the dark ages!Speaking to BBC Newsnight in a rare interview, Justice Ginsburg reiterated the importance of the free press.â€œI read the Washington Post and the New York Times every day, and I think that the reporters are trying to tell the public the way things are,â€ she said.Justice Ginsburg was nominated by Bill Clinton and is regarded as a liberal.Justice Ginsburg was careful to avoid commenting directly on Donald Trumpâ€™s presidency.Before the election, in July 2016, Justice Ginsburg criticised Donald Trump â€“ calling him â€œa fakerâ€. She later said she regretted making the comments.Watch:â€œThink of what the press has done in the United States,â€ she said citing the Watergate scandal. â€œThat story might never have come out if we didnâ€™t have the free press that we do.â€Asked about the rise of the so-called â€œpost truth worldâ€, Justice Ginsburg said: â€œI am optimistic in the long run. A great man once said that the true symbol of the United States is not the bald eagle. It is the pendulum.â€œAnd when the pendulum swings too far in one direction it will go back.â€œSome terrible things have happened in the United States but one can only hope that we learn from those bad things.â€Justice Ginsburg said she was encouraged by the Womenâ€™s March, which saw millions in the US and around the world take part in anti-Trump protests.â€œIâ€™ve never seen such a demonstration â€“ both the numbers and the rapport of the people in that crowd. There was no violence, it was orderly. So yes, we are not experiencing the best times but there is there is reason to hope that that we will see a better day.â€Justice Ginsburg has been on the Supreme Court since 1993 and â€“ at 83 years-old â€“ is the oldest serving member.Asked how much longer she would stay in post, she said: â€œAt my age you have to take it year by year. I know Iâ€™m OK. What will be next year?â€She added: â€œIâ€™m hopeful however, because my most senior colleague the one who most recently retired, Justice John Paul Stevens, stepped down at age 90. So I have a way to go.â€ â€“ BBCNew York Times 2005: â€œJustice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court embraced the practice of consulting foreign legal decisionsâ€¦rejecting the argument from conservatives that United States law should not take international thinking into account.â€â€œI would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experiences would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasnâ€™t lived that lifeâ€ â€“ Supreme Court Justice SotomayorAs the main stream media does a hit job on Donald Trump for expressing his view that the presiding judge in the Trump University case is biased against him because of Trumpâ€™s views on immigration, we have a RACIST Latina Supreme Court Justice whoâ€™s openly declaring that the ethnicity and sex of a judge makes a difference in their judging! So which is it? Â The left wants to have it both ways but theyâ€™re being outed as totalÂ hypocrites! Unreal!Â Â Judge Sotomayor questioned whether achieving impartiality â€œis possible in all, or even, in most, cases.â€ She added, â€œAnd I wonder whether by ignoring our differences as women or men of color we do a disservice both to the law and society.â€AND THEYâ€™RE CALLING TRUMP A RACIST?WASHINGTON â€” In 2001, Sonia Sotomayor, an appeals court judge, gave a speech declaring that the ethnicity and sex of a judge â€œmay and will make a difference in our judging.â€In her speech, Judge Sotomayor questioned the famous notion â€” often invoked by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg and her retired Supreme Court colleague, Sandra Day Oâ€™Connor â€” that a wise old man and a wise old woman would reach the same conclusion when deciding cases.â€œI would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experiences would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasnâ€™t lived that life,â€ said Judge Sotomayor, who is now considered to be near the top of President Obamaâ€™s list of potential Supreme Court nominees.Her remarks, at the annual Judge Mario G. Olmos Law and Cultural Diversity Lecture at the University of California, Berkeley, were not the only instance in which she has publicly described her view of judging in terms that could provoke sharp questioning in a confirmation hearing.This month, for example, a video surfaced of Judge Sotomayor asserting in 2005 that a â€œcourt of appeals is where policy is made.â€ She then immediately adds: â€œAnd I know â€” I know this is on tape, and I should never say that because we donâ€™t make law. I know. O.K. I know. Iâ€™m not promoting it. Iâ€™m not advocating it. Iâ€™m â€” you know.â€The video was of a panel discussion for law students interested in becoming clerks, and she was explaining the different experiences gained when working at district courts and appeals courts. Her remarks caught the eye of conservative bloggers who accused her of being a â€œjudicial activist,â€ although Jonathan H. Adler, a professor at Case Western Reserve University law school, argued that critics were reading far too much into those remarks.Republicans have signaled that they intend to put the eventual nominee under a microscope, and they say they were put on guard by Mr. Obamaâ€™s statement that judges should have â€œempathy,â€ a word they suggest could be code for injecting liberal ideology into the law.Judge Sotomayor has given several speeches about the importance of diversity. But her 2001 remarks at Berkeley, which were published by the Berkeley La Raza Law Journal, went further, asserting that judgesâ€™ identities will affect legal outcomes.â€œWhether born from experience or inherent physiological or cultural differences,â€ she said, for jurists who are women and nonwhite, â€œour gender and national origins may and will make a difference in our judging.â€Her remarks came in the context of reflecting her own life experiences as a Hispanic female judge and on how the increasing diversity on the federal bench â€œwill have an effect on the development of the law and on judging.â€In making her argument, Judge Sotomayor sounded many cautionary notes. She said there was no uniform perspective that all women or members of a minority group have, and emphasized that she was not talking about any individual case.She also noted that the Supreme Court was uniformly white and male when it delivered historic rulings against racial and sexual discrimination. And she said she tried to question her own â€œopinions, sympathies and prejudices,â€ and aspired to impartiality.Still, Judge Sotomayor questioned whether achieving impartiality â€œis possible in all, or even, in most, cases.â€ She added, â€œAnd I wonder whether by ignoring our differences as women or men of color we do a disservice both to the law and society.â€Read more: NYTÂ Â Â Â

I love you momma, you wont have to stand alone
#ibelieveher

#timesupKeith Ellison Keith Ellison for Attorney General Jason Sole Shvonne L Johnson Will Moore @Shiranthi Goonathilaka Stephen Davis Kiree Jamar Robinson Kendra Weiland Deanna Casablanca Valentine F Ndi Justin Monahan StarTribune.com Pioneer Press Lindsey Port Erin Maye Quade Debra Hilstrom Matt Pelikan Hosie Thurmond IIIMy name is Austin Monahan and I am writing this letter on behalf of me and my brother.My brother and I watched our mom come out of pure hell after getting out of her relationship with Keith Ellison. statement:
A majority of city council members in Chicago want to give out free money to citizens even though the city is strapped for cash. They wantÂ Â Mayor Rahm Emanuel to form a task force to look into Universal Basic Income where the people would get a government check with no strings attached aka free money on the backs of the taxpayers.The typical amount would be $500 a month to 1,000 needy Chicago families. Those families would also get Earned Income Tax Credit money on a monthly basis instead of once a year.A rep for one of the Chicago Wards said that the program would â€œhelp working people and families become more resilient to day-to-day financial emergencies, are able to make rent, cover childcare, and put food on the table.â€Obama endorsed Universal Basic Income during a speech in South Africa:Â â€œWeâ€™re going to have to be more imaginative. Weâ€™re going to have to consider new ways of thinking about these problems like a universal income, a review of our work week and how we train our young people.â€More and more politicians are pushing socialism whereby citizens spread the wealth. Remember Joe the Plumber? Obama told Joe he believes in â€œspreading the wealthâ€ way back then and is now pushing it around the world. Itâ€™s a globalists dream to take your hard-earned money and spread it around to other people. Unbelievable!Keith Ellison has been a big supporter of UBI and has spoken about it several timesâ€¦Democrats are down with the program.KEITH ELLISONâ€™S CLAIM THAT UBI WILL ALLOW PEOPLE TO â€œDO OTHER THINGS THAT ARE NECESSARYâ€Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]This is how far left the Democrats have gone. Keith Ellison deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee, recently praised the concept of a universal basic income, saying it â€œhas a lot of merit.â€ Weâ€™d like to know how Ellison plans on paying for all Americans to basically receive an allowance for doing nothing (see more on this below)Ellison made the comment at a forum in Minneapolis:Ellison: Idea of Universal Basic Income â€˜Has a Lot of Meritâ€™Rep. Keith Ellison (D., Minn.), deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee, recently praised the concept of a universal basic income, saying it "has a lot of merit."Ellison made the comment at a forum in Minneapolis, where he discussed the issue of people losing their jobs due to technological advancements.Read more here: https://bit.ly/2GTXFlcPosted by Washington Free Beacon on Thursday, March 29, 2018WFB reports:â€œI personally do think that universal basic income is a [sic] idea that has a lot merit,â€ Ellison said. â€œI donâ€™t think that universal basic income means that people sit around; I think it means do other things that are necessary.â€â€œThere are things that are valuable and important that donâ€™t necessarily have a market value that we should have people doing,â€ Ellison continued. â€œYou know, like in the 1930s, we paid artists to basically document the Depression. We went out and had writers document rural life in America. There were still people who had been enslaved who were still living. During the Depression we paid people to go interview them so we can keep that knowledge, and you can go to the Library of Congress and listen to them today because of it.â€â€œI think that it is a very important idea. Iâ€™ve written on it,â€ Ellison added. â€œIâ€™ve actually thought about having a community meeting on universal basic income because I think itâ€™sâ€”to folks to who know anything about it, thereâ€™s a lot of unanswered questions.â€Proposals for universal basic income programs can vary, but they generally involve the government ensuring that all citizens make a certain minimum amount of money every year, including people without an income.MORE ON UNIVERSAL BASIC INCOME:Forget social security, medicaid and WIC, todayâ€™s progressives have moved well beyond discussing such entitlement relics of the past and nowadays dedicate their efforts to the concept of a â€œUniversal Basic Incomeâ€ for allâ€¦call it the New â€˜New Dealâ€™.Â  You know, because having to work for that â€œcar in every garage and chicken in every potâ€ is just considered cruel and unusual punishment by todayâ€™s standards.Of course, it should come as little surprise that the progressive state of Hawaii, which depends on easily automatable jobs tied to the tourism industry, is among the first to pursue a Universal Basic Income for its residents.Â  And while the idea of passing out free money to everyone seems like a genius plan, if we understand it correctly, as CBS points out, there is just one catchâ€¦figuring out who will pay for it.
Driverless trucks. Factory robots. Delivery drones. Virtual personal assistants.As technological innovations increasingly edge into the workplace, many people fear that robots and machines are destined to take jobs that human beings have held for decadesâ€“a trend that is already happening in stores and factories around the country. For many affected workers, retraining might be out of reach â€”unavailable, unaffordable or inadequate.Over the past two decades, automation has reduced the need for workers, especially in such blue-collar sectors as manufacturing, warehousing and mining. Many of the jobs that remain demand higher education or advanced technological skills. It helps explain why just 55 percent of Americans with no more than a high school diploma are employed, down from 60 percent just before the Great Recession.Hawaii state lawmakers have voted to explore the idea of a universal basic income in light of research suggesting that a majority of waiter, cook and building cleaning jobs â€” vital to Hawaiiâ€™s tourism-dependent economy â€” will eventually be replaced by machines. The crucial question of who would pay for the program has yet to be determined. But support for the idea has taken root.â€œOur economy is changing far more rapidly than anybodyâ€™s expected,â€ said state Rep. Chris Lee, who introduced legislation to consider a guaranteed universal income.Lee said he felt itâ€™s important â€œto be sure that everybody will benefit from the technological revolution that weâ€™re seeing to make sure no oneâ€™s left behind.â€Read more: Zero HedgeWe think itâ€™s insane and that we already give so much to all of the freebie programs out thereâ€¦this is over the top and like throwing money away! Taxpayers need to revolt!
