NUTSTrending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]MILLER FAMOUSLY TOOK DOWN JIM ACOSTA ON IMMIGRATION:Stephen Miller got the best of Acosta when he schooled him on the Statue of Liberty!Â SOME BACKGROUND ON MILLERâ€™S RISE TO TRUMPâ€™S INNER CIRCLE:AL.com reports:When Jeff Sessions first looked at Stephen Miller, he saw potential in the recent Duke University graduate.Miller, then in his early 20s, took up an offer from the conservative author David Horowitz to visit Capitol Hill to introduce him to members of Congress. Horowitz believed that Miller, who penned conservative columns at Duke and in Horowitzâ€™ Front Page Mag, would be a capable D.C. staffer. A meeting with Sessions was on the top of Millerâ€™s Washington wish list.â€œWhat was supposed to be a 15-minute meeting became an hour-long meeting with the senator,â€ Stephen Boyd, Sessionsâ€™ former communications director who eventually hired Miller. â€œSen. Sessions immediately saw that Stephen Miller was an extraordinary young man who had a deep grasp of conservative politics.â€It wasnâ€™t only Sessions who saw something in Miller.When Donald Trump takes the oath of office on Friday, the 31-year-old Miller will be one of the presidentâ€™s closest confidants, serving as a senior White House advisor. That title, announced last month, comes after Miller worked as a senior policy advisor for the better part of a year on the Trump campaign. Trump also tasked Miller with writing his speech to the Republican National Convention, and initial reports indicated that Miller would be writing the inaugural address. The Trump camp is now saying that the president-elect wrote that one himself, although New York Magazine poked some holes in that claim.While Sessions did not have an opening for Miller at the time of that first meeting nearly 10 years ago, he told Boyd to put him on his radar.â€œHe came out and he said to me, â€˜I want you to keep an eye on him and see if he can be a part of our team one day,'â€ Boyd recalled. After working as a press secretary to two House members, Miller was hired as a communications staffer on the Judiciary Committee, where Sessions was the top Republican.â€œI remember setting up a staff and it was Friday afternoon, and I got the go-ahead to hire a press secretary just to work on Judiciary. [Sessionsâ€™] directions were very clear and he and I discussed it â€“ that it was obvious this was a kid with a lot of talent,â€ Boyd said.Miller would move up the ranks from a Judiciary Committee staffer to press secretary for Sessionsâ€™ office, eventually rising to communications director when Boyd departed to become chief of staff to Rep. Martha Roby, R-Montgomery, in 2012. Miller could not be reached for this story.On the surface, there didnâ€™t seem to be much in common between Sessions, who grew up near Selma, and Miller, who was raised in liberal Southern California.The turning point for Miller came after the Sept. 11 attacks, when he was disgusted with how his high school in Santa Monica ridiculed President George W. Bush and how the liberal-leaning faculty banned conservatives like Horowitz and talk show host Larry Elder from speaking at the school but allowed â€œleftists and a Communistâ€ to address the student body, according to an interview he gave to the Los Angeles Times.â€œDuring that dreadful time of national tragedy, anti-Americanism had spread all over the school like a rash,â€ Miller wrote in a 2003 essay, â€œHow I Changed My Left Wing High School,â€ which Horowitz published. â€œThe co-principal broadcasted his doubts about the morality of the air strikes against the Taliban to the entire school via the PA system. One teacher even dragged the American flag across the floor as we were sending off brave young men to risk their lives for it. It was then that I first took action, writing to prized radio personality Larry Elder. He invited me to discuss these issues on his program, which immediately drew the ire of the teachers, administrators, and even my fellow students. Their resistance only strengthened my resolve.â€Miller continued his conservative advocacy at Duke, when he gained attention for defending the white lacrosse players accused of raping a black stripper (the players were ultimately exonerated) at a time when public opinion was against them. His position led to appearances on cable news, further raising his profile.â€œThree of our fellow students are being put on trial not because of evidence but because of a DAâ€™s incompetence and malice,â€ he wrote in the universityâ€™s student paper. â€œSadly, many in the community have shown that they are not fair minded but would rather hunt for witches than search for justice.â€Millerâ€™s writings were one of the main factors in Boyd hiring him.â€œI focused on his material he had written for the other two members of the House. I was very impressed he had a column in college and he was a very good writer,â€ Boyd recalled. â€œI was impressed with his intellect, I was impressed with his grasp of politics. I was impressed with his ability to get the core of the matter and articulate it in a way [the public would] understand.â€Sessionsâ€™ office later found out that Miller had an uncanny ability to channel the senatorâ€™s when dealing with the press. Colleagues of Millerâ€™s and Sessionsâ€™ told Politico that the two had a â€œmind meld,â€ a quality that Boyd also attested to.â€œMiller has demonstrated an ability to capture the voice of his boss in a way that is very important and also exceeds the ability of most Capitol Hill staff,â€ Boyd said.That voice was mostly flexed on immigration, where explained Sessionsâ€™ views to the public.When his boss was accused by pro-immigration groups of being a demagogue for his opposition to an unsuccessful 2010 bill to grant illegal immigrants amnesty for enrolling in college or enlisting in the military, Miller stuck to the issue instead of responding with another attack.â€œThe DREAM Act is a proposal for mass amnesty that would even include those who have committed serious criminal offenses,â€ he told AL.com in November 2010. â€œIt would add millions of newly authorized workers at a time when Americans are struggling with high unemployment and recession.â€Besides being a conduit between the senator and the media, Miller also played a role on policy matters; he was instrumental in helping Sessions derail the Gang of Eight immigration reform bill in 2014 that would have given illegals a pathway to citizenship. Miller helped put together a briefing book for Republicans filled with talking points and data to bolster their case.â€Boyd said Millerâ€™s involvement on policy was unusual for a communications staffer.â€œIt is rare, although in his case I think it speaks to his grasp on the issues and his understanding as they impact the average man and woman,â€ Boyd said. â€œThereâ€™s no doubt that there was a great trust between Sen. Sessions toward Stephen Miller and they made a great team.â€Millerâ€™s having switched to a high-level position on Trumpâ€™s team at a relatively young age does not come as a shock to Boyd, who said his former colleague has adeptly articulated Trumpâ€™s views.â€œI think personally that Miller was one of the first people to really understand the deep frustration that the American working class is feeling, their concerns with open borders and trade policies that hurt them more than they help, and also brought an ability to channel that energy toward president-elect Trump,â€ he said.Â Â

Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 11, 2018From The Hill: To understand, it helps to begin with the aftermath of theÂ 9/11Â terrorist attacks, when U.S. intel agencies sought to expand their surveillance authority â€” for what seemed like all the right reasons. (For context, a weekÂ before 9/11, Robert Mueller had become FBI director; a month earlier, James Clapper had been named head of the agency that supplies image intel to the CIA, and John Brennan recently had become CIA deputy executive director.)Wiretapping foreigners who could be terrorists isnâ€™t as sensitive an issue, since our law doesnâ€™t give them the same protection as U.S. citizens. The problem comes when wiretaps include U.S. citizens in contact with foreign targets. Thatâ€™s called â€œincidentalâ€ collection.And itâ€™s not just phone calls. Todayâ€™s wiretaps can include everything on the web â€”Â emails, bank accounts, photos, messaging, Facebook posts. So, to alleviate worries that citizensâ€™ rights might be violated through â€œincidentalâ€ spying on foreign targets, the intel agencies adopted strict rules. Later, they decided to store it â€” for a short time â€” but promised that the names of the U.S. citizens would be â€œmasked,â€ or hidden, even internally.Then, they argued that they needed to store the information on U.S. citizens a little longer, and might occasionally need to â€œunmaskâ€ or reveal their names. So he develops a pretext to wiretap a foreigner or a target in contact with that citizen. He then â€œincidentallyâ€ captures the citizenâ€™s information, too. Later, he builds a case for â€œunmaskingâ€ the U.S. citizenâ€™s name, supposedly for national securityÂ or other crucialÂ reasons.Hereâ€™s the best part â€” for the bad actors. Power reportedly told congressional investigators that many of the hundreds of â€œunmaskingâ€ requests in her name in 2016 were not made by her. So the way we navigate that is, thereâ€™s a pretty big difference between what is allowed on Facebook and what gets distribution. What weâ€™re trying to do is make it so that if youâ€™re saying something thatâ€™s untrue on Facebook â€” which youâ€™re allowed to say as long as youâ€™re an authentic person and you adhere to community standards â€” but weâ€™re trying to make it so it doesnâ€™t get that much distribution.â€¦ We donâ€™t always get it right, itâ€™s very complicated, but thatâ€™s our principle.â€Reporter: How do you limit distribution?â€œWhen we have something that a fact checker has told is not true or a lot of our audience is telling us is not true, we limit distribution. We tell our algorithms that this is not something we want to see distributed widely. Thatâ€™s one way. Another way is the way misinformation spreads is by people sharing the content.â€¦ We pop up a module that says, â€˜Our fact checker says is inaccurate, you might not want to do that.â€™ That decreases distribution by 80 percent, itâ€™s very effective at reducing the spread of it.â€Reporter: One of the most prominent organizations youâ€™re working with is Fox News, and theyâ€™re sort of incorrigible about proliferating a lot of misinformation. Can you speak to your reasoning behind that? Why would you want to work with an organization like that when, as you said, youâ€™re trying to limit the spread of false information?At this,Â Rick Van Even, head of global creative strategy at Facebook, jumped in: â€œYeah, well, we have limited time, Iâ€™d like to keep it â€” Fidji doesnâ€™t lead the news organization, Campbell Brown leads thatâ€¦â€Another reporter in the background: Answer the question!â€œWe have limited time â€”â€Another reporter: Weâ€™ll give you time!Â Simo: â€œWe have a range of new shows weâ€™re presenting â€”â€Reporter: But Fox News is still on every day, including the weekends. Theyâ€™re still on this programming list.Simo: â€œSo is CNN â€”â€According to Reuters, Facebookâ€™s plummeting stock price wiped out about $150 billion in market capitalization in under two hours.The company had cautioned investors to expect a big jump in costs because of efforts to address concerns about poor handling of usersâ€™ privacy and to better monitor what users post. Total expenses in the second quarter surged to $7.4 billion, up 50 percent compared with a year ago.Expenses are expected to grow 50 percent to 60 percent compared with last year as the company invests in security, marketing and content acquisition, he said.â€œOver the next several years, we would anticipate that our operating margins will trend towards the mid-30s on a percentage basis,â€ Wehner said, adding that margins would be down for more than two years.Facebookâ€™s operating margin fell to 44 percent in the second quarter from 47 percent a year ago.Facebook saw monthly active users in Europe decline about 1 million people amid the new regulations, Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg said on the conference call.Daily user growth for Facebookâ€™s namesake service has slid in six straight quarters, bringing it to 1.47 billion users in the second quarter from 1.23 billion at the end of 2016 when it became embroiled in political issues.Â Â

He is humble and kind and cheerful and he had big dreams! He is hardworking and tough. statement: The charge of arson for burning on federal land is what sparked the Bundy Protest and occupation of a wildlife refuge (SEE OUR PREVIOUS REPORT BELOW). The 41-day standoff was full of ups and downs but the death of LaVoy Finicum was devastating. Whatâ€™s unbelievable is that the Hammond ranchers were ordered back to jail because a judge said they hadnâ€™t fulfilled the minimum sentence even though evidence at the trial was â€œconflictingâ€.Fox News reports:President Trump just signed the order granting clemency to 76-year-old Dwight Hammond and his son, Steven Hammond, 49, who were convicted of arson in 2012 for fires that burned on federal land in 2001 and 2006. Though they served their original sentences for the conviction â€” Dwight serving three months, Steven serving one year â€” an appellate judge ruled in 2015 that the terms were too short under federal minimum sentencing laws and the Hammonds were resentenced to serve the mandatory minimum.Daily Mail reports:Arson on federal land carries a five-year mandatory minimum sentence, but after the Hammonds were originally sentenced, they argued that the five-year rule was unconstitutional, and the trial court agreed and imposed lesser sentences.But, in a statement from the US Attorneyâ€™s Office, federal law was eventually upheld.â€˜The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, however, upheld the federal law, reasoning that â€œgiven the seriousness of arson, a five-year sentence is not grossly disproportionate to the offenseâ€,â€™ it said.â€˜The court vacated the original, unlawful sentences and ordered that the Hammonds be re-sentenced â€œin compliance with the lawâ€,â€™â€œThe Hammonds are multi-generation cattle ranchers in Oregon imprisoned in connection with a fire that leaked onto a small portion of neighboring public grazing land,â€ the White House said in a statement.Â â€œThe evidence at trial regarding the Hammondsâ€™ responsibility for the fire was conflicting, and the jury acquitted them on most of the charges.â€OUR PREVIOUS REPORT ON THE BUNDY STANDOFF CASE:Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]The Bundy family of Nevada joined with hard-core militiamen Saturday to take over the headquarters of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, vowing to occupy the remote federal outpost 50 miles southeast of Burns â€“ pictured below â€“ for years.The occupation came shortly after an estimated 300 marchers â€“ militia and local citizens both â€“ paraded through Burns to protest the prosecution of two Harney County ranchers, Dwight Hammond Jr. and Steven Hammond, who are to report to prison Monday.Posted on Facebook by Tim Davis on Saturday, 2 January 2016:THE STORY COULD SET THE STAGE FOR A WESTERN-STYLE SOAP OPERA:â€œI call it â€˜as the sagebrush burns,â€™â€ said Erin Maupin of the long and storied history involving the Bureau of Land Management (BLM), special interest groups and the cattle ranchers on the Steens Mountain of Oregon.The latest scene involved two ranchers being sentenced to five years in federal prison for inadvertantly burning about 140 acres of BLM rangeland in two separate fires, years ago. That is an area big enough to feed about three cow-calf pairs for a year in that neck of the woods.Dwight, 73 and son Steven, 46, admitted in a 2012 court case, to lighting two different fires. Both fires started on Hammondsâ€™ private property. An August lightening storm started numerous fires and a burn ban was in effect while BLM firefighters fought those fires. Despite the ban, without permission or notification to BLM, Steven Hammond started several â€œback firesâ€ in an attempt to save the ranchâ€™s winter feed. The â€œback burnâ€ fire break worked and protected the Hammondâ€™s ranch. BLM firefighters saw the back-burn and called it into their headquarters as an â€œarson.â€Sadly, wind drove the back-burn onto federal land, on which the Hammonds paid for grazing rights. Despite this, the US Attorney for Oregon prosecuted the two men, saying they committed arson against federal property along with nine other charges. The jury convicted the men of only two charges, starting the fires they readily admitted to starting.Arson against federal property calls for a mandatory minimum sentence of five years prison. The Hammonds argued that such minimum mandatory sentences were unconstitutional and a judge agreed. He sentenced the two men to LESS than the five years. Not satisfied, the US Attorney appealed and the Ninth US Circuit ordered the District Court to re-sentence the men in accordance with the statute.THE FIRES:The first, in 2001, was a planned burn on Hammondsâ€™ own property to reduce juniper trees that have become invasive in that part of the country. That fire burned outside the Hammondsâ€™ private property line and took in 138 acres of unfenced BLM land before the Hammonds got it put out. No BLM firefighters were needed to help extinguish the fire and no fences were damaged.Dwightâ€™s wife Susan shared some crucial details in an exclusive interview with SuperStation95.â€œThey called and got permission to light the fire,â€ she said, adding that was customary for ranchers conducting range management burns â€“ a common practice in the area.â€œWe usually called the interagency fire outfit â€“ a main dispatch â€“ to be sure someone wasnâ€™t in the way or that weather would be a problem.â€ Susan said her son Steven was told that the BLM was conducting a burn of their own somewhere in the region that very same day, but that they believed there would be no problem with the Hammonds going ahead with their planned fire. The court transcript includes the same information in a recording from that phone conversation.In cross-examination of a prosecution witness, the court transcript also includes admission from Mr. Ward, a range conservationist that the 2001 fire improved the rangeland conditions on BLM.Maupin, a former range technician and watershed specialist who resigned from the BLM in 1999, said that collaborative burns between private ranchers and the BLM had become popular in the late 1990s because local university extension researchers were recommending it as a means to manage invasive juniper that steal water from grass and other cover.â€œJuniper encroachment had become an issue on the forefront and was starting to come to a head. We were trying to figure out how to deal with it on a large scale,â€ said the woman whose family also neighbored the Hammonds for a couple of years.â€œIn 1999, the BLM started to try to do large scale burn projects. We started to be successful on the Steens Mountain especially when we started to do it on a large watershed scale as opposed to trying to follow property lines.â€Because private and federal land is intermingled, collaborative burns were much more effective than individual burns that would cover a smaller area, Maupin said.Susan said the second fire, in 2006, was a backfire started by Steven to protect their property from lightening fires.â€œThere was fire all around them that was going to burn our house and all of our trees and everything. The opportunity to set a back-fire was there and it was very successful. It saved a bunch of land from burning,â€ she remembers.The BLM asserts that one acre of federal land was burned by the Hammondsâ€™ backfire and Susan says determining which fire burned which land is â€œa jokeâ€ because fire burned from every direction.Neighbor Ruthie Danielson also remembers that evening and agrees. â€œLightening strikes were everywhere, fires were going off,â€ she said.Maupin said prescribed burns to manage juniper were common in the late 1990s and early 2000s, best done late in the fall when the days are cooler.Prescribed burns on federal land in their area have all but stopped due to pressure from â€œspecial interest groups,â€ Maupin said. As a result, wildfires now burn much hotter due to a â€œladderâ€ of material on the ground â€“ grass, brush and trees.â€œThe fires now burn really hot and they sterilize the ground. Then you have a weed patch that comes back.â€Maupin said planned burning in cooler weather like the Hammonds chose to do improves the quality of the forage, and makes for better sage grouse habitat by removing juniper trees that suck up water and house raptors â€“ a sage grouse predator.â€œJUSTICE FINALLY CAMEâ€Thank goodness some justice finally came to this case! Citing â€œflagrant prosecutorial misconductâ€, a federal judge dismissed charges against the Nevada rancher and three othersâ€¦Cliven Bundy walks out of federal courthouse for first time in nearly two years pic.twitter.com/BHiqgAH8htâ€” David Ferrara (@randompoker) January 8, 2018Fox News reports:A federal judge dismissed all charged against rancher Cliven Bundy and three othersU.S. District Judge Gloria Navarro cited â€œflagrant prosecutorial misconductâ€ in her decision to dismiss all charges against rancher Cliven Bundy, two of his sons and another person.The embarrassment a federal judge dealt to government prosecutors last month in the Cliven Bundy case could be set to resume Monday, at a hearing to determine whether the cattle rancher who became a folk hero long before he beat the feds can be retried.U.S. District Judge Gloria Navarro on Dec. 20 declared a mistrial in the high-profile case. It was only the latest, stunning development in the saga of the Nevada rancher, and served as a repudiation of the federal government. Navarro accused prosecutors of willfully withholding evidence from Bundyâ€™s lawyers, in violation of the federal Brady rule.The Brady rule, named after the landmark 1963 Supreme Court case known as Brady v. Maryland, holds that failure to disclose such evidence violates a defendantâ€™s right to due process.Navarro had suspended the trial earlier and warned of a mistrial when prosecutors released information after a discovery deadline. Overall, the government was late in handing over more than 3,300 pages of documents. Further, some defense requests for information that ultimately came to light had been ridiculed by prosecutors as â€œfantasticalâ€ and a â€œfishing expedition.â€â€œEither the government lied or [its actions were] so grossly negligent as to be tantamount to lying,â€ Napolitano said. â€œThis happened over and over again.â€Navarro said Monday it was clear the FBI was involved in the prosecution and it was not a coincidence that most of the evidence that was held back â€“ which would have worked in Bundyâ€™s favor â€“ came from the FBI, AZCentral reported.ANOTHER BLACK EYE FOR THE FBI AND COMEYâ€¦

Bush appointed federal appeals court judge.â€œThere is no one in America more qualified for this position, and no one more deserving. This incredibly qualified candidate deserves a swift confirmation.â€President Donald Trump has picked Brett Kavanaugh, a federal appeals court judge with extensive legal credentials and a lengthy political record, to succeed Justice Anthony M. Kennedy on the Supreme Court.â€œJudge Kavanaugh has impeccable credentials,â€ Trump said, shortly after announcing his pick. â€œThroughout legal circles, he is considered a true judgeâ€™s judge.â€Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]Kavanaugh, 53, is an ideological conservative who is expected to push the court to the right on a number of issues including business regulation and national security. statement: Unfortunately, the left has fallen prey to the belief that many Americans hold, which is that Lady Liberty has something to do with immigration; that is just not at all the case.Â The Statue of Liberty represents Libertas, Roman goddess of Liberty. Â The words on it were to commemorate July 4th, 1776.The famous poem that does refer to immigration was a part of a poem called The New Colossus, and it included the lines, â€œGive me your tired, give me your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free.â€ The poem was not part of the creation of the Statue of Liberty and was not delivered with the Statue of Liberty. It was written by Emma Lazarus as a part of a contest to help raise money for the statueâ€™s pedestal. Â A bronze tablet bearing the Emma Lazarus poem was only put inside the pedestal in 1903.RUSH LIMBAUGH CALLED OUT OBAMA ON HIS LIES ABOUT THE STATUE OF LIBERTY:There ya go!Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]THE NEW YORK TIMES REPORTED ON THE HISTORY OF THE STATUEâ€¦A left-leaning twist mixed with factsâ€¦When the Goddess of Liberty was given to the United States, its donorâ€™s agenda was to burnish Franceâ€™s republican roots after the oppressive reign of Napoleon III and to celebrate the two nationsâ€™ commitment to the principles of liberty.The only immigrants mentioned at the dedication in 1886 were the â€œillustrious descendants of the French nobilityâ€ who fought on behalf of the United States against Britain during the American Revolution.THE TIMES TRIES TO MAKE IT ABOUT IMMIGRATIONâ€¦ITâ€™S NOT!ITâ€™S A POEMâ€¦NOT A POLICY FOR IMMIGRATION!But it was the words of a fourth-generation American whose father was a wealthy sugar refiner and whose great-great-uncle welcomed George Washington to Newport, R.I., that almost single-handedly transformed the monumental statue in New York Harbor into the â€œMother of Exilesâ€ that would symbolically beckon generations of immigrants.Emma Lazarusâ€™s poem only belatedly became synonymous with the Statute of Liberty, whose 125th birthday as a gift from France will be celebrated on Friday by the National Park Service. Lazarusâ€™s â€œNew Colossus,â€ with its memorable appeal to â€œgive me your tired, your poor,â€ was commissioned for a fund-raising campaign by artists and writers to pay for the statueâ€™s pedestal.But while the poem was critically acclaimed â€” the poet James Russell Lowell wrote that he liked it â€œmuch better than I like the Statue itselfâ€ because it â€œgives its subject a raison dâ€™Ãªtre which it wanted before quite as much as it wants a pedestalâ€ â€” it was not even mentioned at the dedication ceremony.Finally in 1903, after relentless lobbying by a friend of Lazarus who was descended from Alexander Hamilton, himself an immigrant, it was â€œaffixed to the pedestal as an ex post facto inscription,â€ the art historian Marvin Trachtenberg wrote.â€œGradually, thereafter, the awareness spread not only of the significance of the lines of the poem but also of the significance of the aspect of national tradition it expressed,â€ another historian, Oscar Handlin, wrote. â€œLiberty was not simply the bond between ancient allies; nor was it only the symbol of liberal ideas of justice and freedom; it was also the motive force that had peopled the wilderness and made the country that emerged what it was.â€Barry Moreno, a historian of the statue for the National Park Service, recalled that it â€œwas never built for immigrants.â€â€œIt was,â€ he recalled, â€œbuilt to pay tribute to the United States of America, the Declaration of Independence, American democracy, and democracy throughout the world. It honored the end of slavery, honored the end of all sorts of tyranny and also friendship between France and America.â€THE LEFT HIJACKS THE MEANING OF THE STATUE:Only later, he added, â€œletters were written home, word of mouth, taught people that you would see this wonderful goddess in New York Harbor when you arrived in America to welcome you.â€â€œAnd she became really famous among immigrants,â€ he recalled. â€œAnd it was really immigrants that lifted her up to a sort of a glory that was probably before America really fully embraced her.â€Lazarus, who popularized that â€œwonderful goddess,â€ accepted the commission only begrudgingly â€” few poets relish the idea of writing on demand. But she was stirred by a wave of pogroms against Jews in Russia and by her regular visits to poor immigrants housed in temporary shelters on Wards Island. She would make â€œThe New Colossusâ€ the first entry in a compendium of poems she anthologized shortly before her death from Hodgkinâ€™s disease at 38 in 1887.The poem went unmentioned in her obituary in The New York Times, but it appeared in a brief article in 1903 when the plaque was dedicated. (An exhibition on Lazarus, the â€œPoet of Exiles,â€ opens Wednesday at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Lower Manhattan.A manuscript of the poem is at the Center for Jewish History.)â€œEmma Lazarus was the first American to make any sense of this statue,â€™â€™ said Esther Schor, an English professor at Princeton and author of a biography titled â€œEmma Lazarus.â€â€œConceived by the French statesman Ã‰douard RenÃ© de Laboulaye, the statue was to propound the values of the French Revolution, in a sort of end-run around the repressive Second Empire of Napoleon III,â€ Professor Schor said. â€œBut Americans were so unmoved and uninterested that it was hard to raise money simply to build a pedestal to support it.â€For Lazarus, who wrote the sonnet in 1883 having seen only the torch when it was on display for a fund-raising drive in Madison Square Park, â€œit was a moment of moral and spiritual recovery, after her attempts to raise money to benefit the Russian-Jewish refugees of 1881-82 had largely fallen on deaf ears,â€ Professor Schor said.Instead of retreating, she broadened her appeal to all immigrants, Professor Schor said. For her â€œthe statue was a special kind of mother â€” a â€˜mother of exilesâ€™ â€” a mother whose mission is not to reproduce herself, but rather to adopt the abandoned, the orphaned, the persecuted,â€ she said.â€œSheâ€™s tender and accepting,â€ Professor Schor said, â€œbut also fiercely protective, and her iconoclastic message smashes the icons of enlightenment and imperialism.â€The sonnet would survive periodic efforts to excise her reference to â€œwretched refuseâ€ and would become enshrined in the political lexicon in the 1930s as an anthem for Americans who, with war again threatening in Europe, lobbied to reverse anti-immigration quotas that had been imposed a decade earlier.â€œThe irony is that the statue goes on speaking, even when the tide turns against immigration â€” even against immigrants themselves, as they adjust to their American lives,â€™â€™ Professor Schor said. â€œYou canâ€™t think of the statue without hearing the words Emma Lazarus gave her.â€Â

statement:
Â Texas Border Volunteers are working day and night to help keep illegal aliens from crossing over into the US. Â The TBVÂ rarely gets the credit they deserve, however, for preventing dangerous illegal aliens from entering Texas via Mexico.Â Meet the Texas Border Volunteersâ€¦
Just before sundown, a group of men cloaked in camouflage from the Texas Border Volunteers halts their all-terrain vehicle, along a winding sandy road. As they make their way around the heavy brush, they circle around a pile of womenâ€™s undergarments, which lay at the foot of a tree. In sections of land near the U.S.-Mexico border, this is known as a â€œrape tree.â€ And for the residents of Brooks County, Texas, rape trees are popping up at an alarming frequency.â€œIâ€™ve had three rape cases in the last month,â€ says Benny Martinez, the chief deputy at the Brooks County Sheriffâ€™s Department. â€œThese guys are animals. There is an intimidation factor there. If they donâ€™t give into the brush guide, [the women] get beat up.â€The group who found the â€œrape treeâ€ are part of the Texas Border Volunteers, a troop of a few dozen private citizens who spend their own time â€“ six or seven hours at a clip â€“ weaving through the low-hanging honey mesquite trees and heavy Texas brush looking to stop immigrants from crossing into this land â€“ and their country â€“ illegally.Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]Symbols like the rape tree serve as a reminder to volunteers or anyone passing through of the escalating brutality â€œcoyotesâ€ are using to control immigrants they lead through this land. The tree is a traffickerâ€™s way of asserting power. But it also serves as a landmark for the border volunteers, allowing them to keep a record of immigrant migration patterns through the brush.When the Texas Border Volunteers head into the muggy summer night, each member gathers night vision goggles, flashlights, guns and folding chairs.They run their shift as if they had been given marching orders from a commanding officer. They run their operation like a military mission, with code names like â€œgumballâ€ and â€œpolecatâ€ buzzing across their walkie-talkies.Founded in 2006, the Texas Border Volunteers began as a citizen response to the growing amount of property damage occurring on the wide swath of private ranch land in Brooks County, Texas, an area 70 miles north of the U.S.-Mexico border. The county is home to the final border patrol checkpoint before human and drug smugglers funnel their inventory north. To get around the border patrol station, drivers often unload their cargo on desolate county roads and smuggle it through the dusty Texas fields for dozens of miles where they can hide among the thick landscape, sometimes for days.The volunteers who patrol the ranch lands come from all walks of life; a mix of retired military personnel, educators, small business owners and computer technicians. While some live in the area, others come all the way from north Texas, or even out of state, to lend a hand. When they arenâ€™t on patrol, they sleep in a garage bunker or in tents on the ranch.Texas Border Volunteer Jim Gibson is wearing one of our Defend Your Constitution Before Itâ€™s Too Weak To Defend You T-shirts that can be found in our store on the 100percentfedup.com website.
Veterinarian and rancher Michael Vickers, who has lived in Brooks County since 1986, founded Texas Border Volunteers out of desperation.â€œThey started cutting our fences and they broke into my house and tore up our water sources, breaking the floats off. And it has just been escalating,â€ Vickers says. â€œThe groups are getting bigger and the people are more combative.â€Vickersâ€™ wife, Linda, never leaves the house without her cell phone, a gun and her four guard dogs.Ranchers in the area say immigrants used to pass through without much of a trace.â€œIt used to be mostly Mexican peasants coming to look for work,â€ Vickers says. â€œMaybe a couple times a week, theyâ€™d show up at my front door, ring the doorbell and ask if I had any work for them. If I didnâ€™t, Iâ€™d send them across the road or point them in the direction of work. They were very respectful. Weâ€™d give them water, weâ€™d give them food.â€Now, all along Route 281, bended fences, abandoned clothing and empty Gatorade bottles lay scattered on the road, evidence of groups passing through. Via: US News

statement: In January of this year, many conservative facebook groups saw a sudden drop in traffic while the left-leaning groups remained the same or even saw a rise in readership. President Trumpâ€™s own Facebook page saw a 45% drop in readership! Many conservative publishers have chosen not to fight. This is disturbing! This has raised questions of whether censorship has taken hold of the social media platforms that for so long boasted of being free speech platforms for all opinions.One of the most disturbing developments has been that the platforms are using the Southern Poverty Law Center to decide what hate speech policies to implement. The Liberal Democrat leader, Tim Farron, called it a â€œwake-up callâ€.In October, the Sentencing Council published draft guidelines for stiffer sentences for people carrying knives. In Manchester, parents of a 14-year-old were ordered to pay Â£1,000 to a boy their son stabbed several times outside school. Every kitchen contains lethal knives which are potential murder weapons.â€œAccordingly, it is very easy for any youth who wants to obtain a knife to take it from the kitchen drawer in his home or in the home of one of his friends.â€As a result â€“ said the judge â€“ the most common knife a youth will take out is eight to ten inches, long and pointed, from his motherâ€™s cutlery tray.He asked: â€œBut why we do need eight-inch or ten-inch kitchen knives with points?â€œButchers and fishmongers do, but how often, if at all, does a domestic chef use the point of an eight-inch or ten-inch knife? Weâ€™re here to dull the blades on your knives and round the tips, so you canâ€™t stab anyone with them.â€Criminal: â€œNo problem, Iâ€™ll be right there with all of my knives. statement: Dan Bongino drops a huge new piece of information on when the spying started on the Trump campaign. The FBI is hiding paragraph oneâ€¦The FBI refuses to tell what paragraph one isâ€¦WHY?Bongino says weâ€™re focusing on â€œthe pullâ€â€¦.The real question is how was the email information about the Russian dirt fed to the campaign? Â It was fed to the campaign by a professor who has now disappeared:Painting a full picture of Mifsud is difficult because after the 58-year-old professor was first identified by name in a Washington Post article in the weeks following Papadopoulosâ€™ confession, he gave a few interviews to the international press, and then disappeared.Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]Real Clear Politics reports:In the shifting narratives of the Trump-Russia probe, a Maltese academic named Joseph Mifsud has remained a linchpin regarding claims of collusion. He is the professor who allegedly told Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos that the Russians had emails related to the Clinton campaign. The FBI says it opened its investigation in late July 2016 after Papadopoulos relayed that information to Australian diplomat Alexander Downer, and the Australians tipped off U.S. authorities.While some news accounts describe Mifsud as an accomplice to Russian clandestine operations or a â€œcut-outâ€ (intermediary), others contend he is a full-fledged Russian spy.In an official report, Democrats on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence asserted that â€œin their approach to Papadopoulos, the Russians used common tradecraft and employed a cut-out,â€ a â€œKremlin-linkedâ€¦Maltese professor named Joseph Mifsud.â€No one in the American intelligence community has publicly challenged this description.But there is one major problem with this story: No evidence has been presented to support the claim. Although Mifsud has traveled many times to Russia and has contacts with Russian academics, his closest public ties are to Western governments, politicians, and institutions, including the CIA, FBI and British intelligence services. One of Mifsudâ€™s jobs has been to train diplomats, police officers, and intelligence officers at schools in London and Rome, where he lived and worked over the last dozen years.Â The house-of-mirrors nature of the claim that Mifsud is a spy is reflected in the guilty plea Papadopoulos signed on Oct. 5, 2017 for making several material false statements to the FBI. It reads, in part: â€œDefendant PAPADOPOULOS further told the investigating agents that the professor was â€˜a nothingâ€™ and â€˜just a guy talk[ing] up connections or something.â€™ In truth and in fact, however, defendant PAPADOPOULOS understood that the professor had substantial connections to Russian government officials (and had met with some of those officials in Moscow immediately prior to telling defendant PAPADOPOULOS about the â€˜thousands of emailsâ€™) and, over a period of months, defendant PAPADOPOULOS repeatedly sought to use the professorâ€™s Russian connections in an effort to arrange a meeting between the Campaign and Russian government officials.â€If Mifsud truly is a Russian agent â€“ which is key to the collusion narrative â€“ he could prove to be one of the most promiscuous spies in modern history. Western intelligence agencies and European politicians would have to spend the next few decades repairing the damage he did to global security by infiltrating key institutions and personnel. As of yet, however, there is no indication that any intelligence service has begun the embarrassing, but highly important, assessment of how it was penetrated and how it can re-fortify the vulnerabilities that Mifsud may have exposed. There has been no public effort to arrest him.

A new sign at a longstanding Philly watering hole has some of the neighborhoodâ€™s newcomers outraged.Itâ€™s a sign that wouldâ€™ve stopped Michelle Obama dead in her tracks, unless, of course, her husband was President of the United Statesâ€¦About 15 minutes into my Thursday-night visit to Old Philadelphia Bar, the inevitable happened. A man, who said he was a former firefighter before saying that he was a Mexican, which he then said was â€œjust a jokeâ€ (the Mexican part), walked up to the jukebox, put his money inside, and played the 1984 Lee Greenwood hit â€œGod Bless the USA.â€ And as the anthemic chorus began, many of the patriotic patrons at the bar joined in:And Iâ€™m proud to be an American
Where at least I know Iâ€™m free
And I wonâ€™t forget the men who died
Who gave that right to me
And Iâ€™d gladly stand up next to you
And defend Her still today
â€™Cause there ainâ€™t no doubt
I love this land
God Bless the U.S.A.Itâ€™s a fitting theme song for the smoky little bar at the corner of Martha and Dauphin streets in the Kensington section of Philadelphia â€” just around the corner from popular spots like Pizza Brain and Martha, and just across the border from Fishtown. The sign on the front door reads: â€œIF YOUâ€™RE NOT PROUD TO BE AN AMERICAN, DO NOT BOTHER TO COME IN.â€Trending: KATIE HOPKINS WARNS AMERICANS Of Grave Danger Ahead: â€œDo Not Let This Great Country Become The United Kingdomâ€ [VIDEO]The sign doesnâ€™t say â€œIf youâ€™re not an American, do not bother to come inâ€ it simply states that if youâ€™re not â€œproudâ€ to be America, do not bother to come in.Earlier this week, a passerby took notice of the door signage and posted it to a Facebook community group, where outrage ensued. One person joked that the bar must belong to Joey Vento, the late owner of Genoâ€™s Steaks, who infamously and proudly displayed that â€œTHIS IS AMERICA â€¦ SPEAK ENGLISHâ€ sign at the iconic cheesesteak shop.One young Fairmount woman who saw the image said sheâ€™d be sure to skip Old Philadelphia Bar â€” the locals simply call it Old Philly â€” because her boyfriend is an Indian man who has a beard.â€œI would avoid going there,â€ she told me. â€œItâ€™s usually fine. Sometimes, some places, itâ€™s not fine. As is obvious from that sign.â€But the staff and regulars inside Old Philadelphia Bar donâ€™t understand what all the fuss is about, and a bar manager told Philly Mag that, if anything, the addition of the sign has increased business.â€œIf youâ€™re in this country, you should be proud to be an American,â€ one Old Philadelphia bartender told me.â€œBut what about people who are in this country who simply arenâ€™t American?â€ I asked her. â€œHow should they feel about a sign like that?â€She shrugged and said, â€œWe love everybody here â€¦ Besides, a Spanish guy put it up for us.â€Some local residents are reportedly considering filing a complaint about the Old Philadelphia sign with the Philadelphia Commission on Human Relations, the cityâ€™s civil rights agency. Of course, a complaint filed with the PCHR over the Genoâ€™s sign resulted in a ruling that the sign was not discriminatory, and it remained displayed at Genoâ€™s Steaks until 2016, five years after Joey Ventoâ€™s death. â€“Philly MagÂ
